item.title: antinode
item.description: on the peak of a standing wave the place where [[standing waves]] experience the highest amplitude of oscillations

item.title: characteristic wave speeds
item.description: $c_{light}=3\cdot 10^8 m/s$ (speed of light in vacuum) $c_{sound}=343m/s$ (speed of sound in air)

item.title: class problems
item.description: [!note] Missing wavelength $f=200Hz$ $c=340Hz$ $\lambda=?$ $$c=\lambda\cdot f$$ $$\lambda=\frac{c}{f}=>\frac{340Hz}{200Hz}$$ $$\lambda=1.7m$$ [!note] Missing period What is the period of red light?

item.title: emulsification
item.description: mixing of two liquids that do not mix by dispersing one into tiny droplets

item.title: human sound
item.description: Three components lungs [[vocal folds]] (within larynx) articulators ([[tongue]], cheek, lips) Voice type affected by the size of the [[vocal folds|vocal chords]] and vocal tract

item.title: infrasound
item.description: Q: What are the uses of infrasound? animal communication

item.title: Longitudinal waves
item.description: oscillaiton is parallel to propagation compressions, parefactions

item.title: oscillations on a string
item.description: two fixed ends ([[node]]) $L$ units apart 1st harmonic $\lambda=2L$ $$f=\frac{c}{\lambda}$$ $f=\frac{c}{2L}$ 1st overtone (2nd harmonic) $\lambda=L$

item.title: reflection
item.description: “visszaverődés” [!important] Reflection at the border of a new medium, the waves turn back At a fixed end, crests become throughs and vice versa

item.title: sound
item.description: Sound is a [[Longitudinal waves|longitudinal wave]] spreading in a flexible medium that is perceivable by the [[ears|ear]]. ([[human sound]]) Pitch is determined by frequency

item.title: standing waves
item.description: They are created by the superposition of two waves with identical properties (A, f, $\lambda$) spreading in opposite directions. distance between to [[node]]s (or [[antinode]]s) is half the wavelength

item.title: superposition
item.description: When two or more [[waves]] travelling in a medium meet, their oscillations are added. The waves pass through each other.

item.title: ultrasound
item.description: Q: What are the uses of low energy ultrasound? imaging technique pest control Q: What are the uses of high energy of ultrasound?

item.title: vocal folds
item.description: Anatomy chords attached at the back side to the arytenoids cartilages, to the thyroid cartilages in the front

item.title: waves
item.description: [[Longitudinal waves]] [[Wave behavior]] Wave characteristics wavelength = $\lambda$ $f_{wave}=f_{oscillation}$ $T_{wave}=T_{oscillation}$ [!important] Wave speed the speed at which waves propagate in a medium
